titleStmt.title: Letters from S. A. Brown and Edna Hordson to Eartha M. M. White and unknown. November 11, 1931.
titleStmt.author: S. A. Brown and Edna Hordson

publicationStmt.p: This document forms part of the project "Editing the Earth M.M. White Collection" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

msContents.summary: The first author writes to White describing their physical health and a package being sent to her. The second author writes a personal letter to an unknown recipient.

objectDesc.p: A handwritten letter from Brown to White, written on 11/11/1931. The letter is divided into four pages on a single sheet of folded paper. It is accompanied by its envelope and the envelope and final page of a letter from Edna Hordson to an unknown recipient.

div.p:
Please don’t be shocked
by reception of a letter
from me.

After a trying summer
in the dentist’s chair, with
in four weeks, I had to get
sick and I almost died. Then
within a week after getting

up and out from that at
tack, I was suddenly seized
one night with another attack
of something else. It seemed
that that would finish me,
God was with me all the
way, and I am here, ask
ing how you are, and how
and where the wanderer
is.

I have not heard from
him, since his famous speech
at St. Augustine. I heard of
it, here,.

I would have called you,
but to be sure of finding
you home, I struck upon the
plan of calling somewhere
around 12 oclocko'clock, at night.

Then, I thought that I might
arouse you from a refreshing
and much needed sleep after
a hard day’s work, so I just
put off and put off meeting
till this almost disgraceful
period of silence.

Forgive and forget and
let me hear from you, some

way by phone, letter or in per
son.

Love to Lucy and everybody
of our group.

Look out for a small pack
age soon. I know you, like
me, are looking for your
stockings. I got us some, and
will forward yours soon,

P.S.
Dr. Haring spoke before the
student body this a.m. and to
our neighborhood club this p.m.
She was well received.

3.
All of this enlivens my time. Of
course I am never at a loss
for things to do since there is
always so many things to think
about as to our present problems.

Do you find anytime to read,
busy as you are, about the real
practical side of our many
problems? After all it better
to do than to dream. Well
this is not a merry letter but
I will do better next time.

Lots of love, Take care of
your health. Think of me some
times.

Miss Eartha M. M. White,
233 W.West First St.Street,
Jacksonville
Fla.Florida
